terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Yorkshire coast. Moderate elevation with coastal scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional UK event. Yorkshire coast terrain with small-medium local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Yorkshire Coast Dirt Dash is a regional event in UK‚ÄîYorkshire coast terrain with moderate elevation. The coast is scenic, but the small-medium local field, regional organization, and limited prestige keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional UK Yorkshire coast gravel race. Worth it for UK riders. Not worth traveling internationally for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to UK‚Äîyes, it's solid. If you're traveling internationally‚Äîskip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better UK races: Lauf Gritfest.

logistics.food: Whitby has excellent dining. Stock nutrition.
logistics.official_site: Check Yorkshire Coast Dirt Dash website

history.origin_story: Regional UK Yorkshire coast gravel event.

non_negotiables.why: UK coastal weather is variable with rain possible.
Yorkshire coast requires sustained coastal effort.

topics.weather: Riding in variable UK coastal weather

logistics.explanation: Start/finish at YHA Whitby with electronic rider briefing and GPX files provided beforehand. Riders handle their own navigation with no course markings, and registration happens at the event with details 'TBC.' Support vehicle available for rescues only. As Event format [ALL LEVELS] puts it: "non-timed, self-supported reliability trial with overnight camping"

length.explanation: 73 miles split over two days with overnight camping - Day 1 covers 58.8km, Day 2 covers 59.5km. The format is a non-timed reliability trial with night riding restrictions unless using lights, making it more touring than racing distance. More compact than Grinduro.

technicality.explanation: Mix of singletrack, gravel paths, forestry roads through North York Moors with mandatory 45mm minimum tires. Routes designed by Markus Stitz, 'a seasoned route designer with multiple gravel and bikepacking guidebooks to his name.' E-bikes allowed. Less technical than The Mid South. As Event requirements [ALL LEVELS] puts it: "mountain bikes & gravel bikes with a minimum recommended tire size of 45mm, which must be in good working order, e-bikes are alowed"

elevation.explanation: Day 1 includes approximately 840m of climbing, Day 2 adds 970m through North York Moors National Park terrain. Split over two days with overnight camping, the elevation is manageable rather than mountainous by gravel standards. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: 2024 conditions were described as 'A very wet weekend' in rider footage. June/July timing in Yorkshire Coast location means variable British weather with potential coastal wind effects and rapid weather changes. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Starting at sea level in Whitby and climbing through North York Moors means modest elevation gains. No altitude effects or thin air concerns - just rolling British countryside terrain. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds ‚Äî no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Self-supported navigation through North York Moors and Yorkshire Coast with overnight wild camping and mandatory bivvy gear. Extensive kit requirements including emergency blanket, waterproof jacket, and first aid kit create bikepacking adventure vibes. As Jenny Graham puts it: "OK, so this is a bit of a cop-out. But because the route has so much wilderness, every coffee opportunity was anticipated and enjoyed! But if I had to pick just one then the little village cafe of Rav..."

prestige.explanation: Event philosophy states 'It's not a race, it's a reliability trial! Stay cool, be nice, don't hurt yourself or others.' Non-timed format with no competitive results or pro field means no racing prestige to speak of.

race_quality.explanation: Professional route design by Markus Stitz with support vehicle and provided meals creates solid event infrastructure. However, it's explicitly not a race - no timing, no competition, just self-navigation through Yorkshire following GPX files.

experience.explanation: Riders report 'It was a great event again. I'm really enjoying the format.' Includes overnight camping, evening meal, breakfast, and 'well-supported, relaxed atmosphere' in stunning North York Moors landscapes.

community.explanation: The Dirt Dash series cultivates a 'big riding family' vibe with many repeat participants returning year after year. That's nice for those who want a social cycling weekend. But small field sizes and the touring format mean you're not joining any significant gravel racing community here.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 75-125 riders, non-competitive reliability trial format means no racing field exists. Everyone rides at their own pace through Yorkshire with no timing or results, creating social ride atmosphere rather than competitive depth. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: ¬£95 includes GPX files, support vehicle, overnight camping, evening meal, breakfast, and professional route design through North York Moors. Described as 'riders come first' philosophy with quirky YHA start/finish location.

expenses.explanation: ¬£95 entry (¬£5 Cycling UK member discount) plus travel to Whitby keeps costs moderate. Extensive mandatory kit list including tent, sleeping gear, lights, tools, and own bowl/mug for meals adds equipment requirements. Higher total cost than Badlands.

citations.label: RideWithGPS: Yorkshire Coast Dirt Dash Day 1
us.alpkit.com: Adventure Cycling In North Yorkshire Route Yc

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Are these idiots for real?
videos.description:
When you've watched this, Watch this - https://youtu.be/euBN2ODkFYw 
Then see if your comments are still valid!

While these signs strongly advise pedestrians to stay off cycling trails for safety, the legal situation is more complex.

The Countryside and Rights of Way Act 2000 (CROW Act) gave the public a new legal right of access to "open access land" in England and Wales. This land primarily includes mountain, moor, heath, and downland, and much of the land managed by Forestry England falls under this category. This means that, by law, the public has a right to walk on this land.

Therefore, while a sign with a crossed-out person is a critical safety warning and should be respected, it does not always represent a legal prohibition. It's a way for Forestry England to manage risk and guide people towards safer, more suitable walking routes.

This reality highlights a significant challenge for forest management: balancing public access rights with the need for user safety. 

I have my opinions on this and clearly not everyone agrees, which is absolutely fine as is your right to agree or disagree. I'm not changing my opinion on the response I got but clearly the signage is not as clear cut as it first appeared.

Let me know your thoughts in the comments below....

videos.title: 5 UK Beginner bikepacking routes YOU SHOULD start with!
videos.description:
In this video, I wanted to share my 5 recommendations for the most beginner-friendly routes that I think you should start with if you are looking for a beginner adventure around the UK the routes get progressively easier as the video goes on, hope you enjoy this video.

Find all the routes and gear here - https://www.keepsmilingadventures.com/

Make a route suggestion here - https://www.keepsmilingadventures.com/route-sugestions

Support the channel by becoming a member
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCPQeFqyxTu9g1IMBlVvG9jg/join
============================================================

If you enjoy the content on this channel and would like to help the adventures continue then head over to my buymeacoffee page where you can buy me a pasty if you like :D https://www.buymeacoffee.com/KSmileadventure

videos.transcript:
[Music]
looking to get started with bik packing
but not sure where to begin in this
video I'll be sharing five beginner
friendly rots across the UK If you are
new to bite packing these are the
perfect routs to help you ease in we're
starting with the most challenging on
the list and working our way down to the
easiest but they are all very much
beginner Roots so let's dive in with the
hardest beginner route
the capital Trail is a fantastic option
if you are looking to start bik packing
in Scotland it's a 150 M Loop starting
and finishing in the capital city
Edinburgh and taking you through the
scenic lowlands although it's a beginner
friendly route some sections lean
towards intermediate making it a great
choice if you are up for a bit of a
challenge
this route can be done on a gravel bike
but you will find a mountain bike makes
the tougher sections easier and a little
more
fun those mountain bike gears are a big
plus too especially for some of the
steeper climbs that will keep you
working hard one section to watch out
for is along the old drove road towards
Peebles it's mostly an unridable long
hiker bike where you'll be pushing the
bike all the way up The Descent does
become manageable at a certain point but
this is definitely the Root's most
challenging stretch it's not for the
faint-hearted but it's all part of the
adventure and if you're looking for a
challenge it's a great route even though
the trails feel remote you're never
actually that far away from civiliz
ization which is nice if you are not
familiar with riding in very remote
places if you are a complete beginner be
prepared for some tough spots there's
plenty of climbing exciting to sense and
the occasional hiker bike so yes it's a
beginner route but it's a Scottish
beginner route meaning it's a good route
to test your resolve plan for around 2
to 4 days to take it all in depending on
your pace and the weather which being
Scotland can be unpredictable the
lowlands may not be as popular as the
highlands but they have their own rugged
charm that makes this ride truly
memorable the capital Trail is
definitely worth a go if you are looking
for a first bik packing Adventure that
will leave you with lasting
memories last year after a series of
illnesses that kept me off the bike I
decided it was time to ease back in with
a familiar and manageable route that's
how the two downs one Forest came to
life a 170 m Loop starting and finishing
in brockenhurst in the New Forest this
route offers a real mix of terrain and
scenery with around 10,000 fet of
elevation gain to keep things
interesting it's definitely beginner
friendly but it's all also fairly lumpy
so be ready for a good workout along the
way the route takes you through three of
seven England's most beautiful
landscapes you start in a New Forest
which is packed with compact gravel
trails and Scenic Woodlands from there
you'll ride into the Rolling Hills of
the South Downs where you will find wide
open spaces and some fast flowing
descents and of course some lung busting
climbs
finally you'll head through to the
Northwest Downs climbing to Gallows down
the route's highest point where you'll
be rewarded with stunning views over the
surrounding Countryside even though it
covers remote feeling Trails this Loop
never takes you too far away from
civilization so you'll always have
plenty of chances to stop and resupply
along the way and that that's a great
benefit for New Riders who want a bit of
Adventure without committing to being
truly
remote the trails are a mix with single
track double track old byways and a few
quiet country lanes to connect things
some of the single track sections I'll
warn you can get a little overgrown in
the summer months so be prepared for the
odd rough patch here and there while you
can absolutely tackle this route on a
gravel bike I'd say a mountain bike
makes it a little more enjoyable
especially on the single track where a
mountain bike position and grippier
tires are a real
plus if you are going the gravel route
I'd recommend at least 45 mm tires to
keep things comfortable on the varied
surfaces the two downs one Forest is all
about discovering the charm of the South
of England from the gravel Tracks Of The
New Forest to the scenic climbs and
sweeping Des scents of the South Downs
this Loop offers some great riding
memorable views and a bit of everything
to make your bik packing Adventure
Unforgettable this might be the only
Welsh bite packing route I'd ever be
able to put on a beginner list but the
ga is a stunning place to discover by
bike located on the southwestern coast
of Wales it has a unique charm that sets
it apart from the more rugged areas of
the country it's softer and less wild
but still beautiful in its own right at
only 50 Mi this route is perfect for a
leisurely day trip or relaxed
overnighter if you want to stretch it
out while this area is less demanding
than much of whales you'll still find a
few steep climbs and descents just to
remind you you are still in Wales so
make sure your brakes are in good work
in order fortunately these climbs are
fairly short but they still give you a
taste of the Rolling Welsh landscape the
route itself is beginner friendly with
most of the trails being straightforward
and easy to navigate you'll follow a
mixture of quiet pave roads and mellow
off-road sections keeps things
interesting without adding too much of a
challenge there are a couple of steep
descents where it's worth taking it slow
and you'll even have a short hiker bike
through some Sandy Junes a nice bit of
variety and a chance to stretch the legs
and enjoy them SE views the go route is
ideal if you're looking for a beginner
friendly Adventure that still has a bit
of everything Scenic coastlines Rolling
Hills and the peaceful Countryside of
Wales it's a great way to experience a
different side of Wales and take in some
Fant fantastic Coastal views all on the
manageable and beautiful side whales can
be a hard place to ride so if you want
to explore Wales you're a beginner the
gawa is a great place to
start cycling UK's Rebellion way is
probably the most beginner friendly bik
packing route I can think of you don't
need any Special K no need for a big
travel bike just a bit of Fitness to
tackle the 230 Mi and since this route
is in Norfolk you won't have to worry
about any lung busting climbs just a
couple of little draggy sections at most
this route primarily follows paved
surfaces including some dedicated cycle
paths and quiet Country Roads however be
prepared for a bit of traffic when
leaving Norwich as it can get a little
busy depending on what time of day you
arrive and leave when you do head
off-road the terrain is beginner
friendly with mostly flat double track
and a couple of narrow Trails the
off-road sections are relatively short
so you'll spend more time riding on Tac
than actually off-road while I wouldn't
recommend using a traditional road bike
a gravel bike a hybrid or a cyc across
bike with tires in the range of around
30 to 35 mm would work just fine just a
little bit of puncture protection for
the off-road sections providing a good
balance of comfort and grip what I love
about the Rebellion way is that it's
more about enjoying the scenery than
testing your limits with steep climbs
it's closer to a touring route over a
bik packing route really but
nevertheless it's perfect for beginners
and a fantastic way to experience the
north Countryside whether you're
planning a 2 to 4 day trip or looking to
stretch it out even longer this route is
a great choice just remember to take it
easy enjoy the ride and embrace the
laidback Vibe of the area be sure to
check out cycling UK for any updates or
to read more about this route it's a
great starting point for anyone looking
to dive into the world of bite packing
there isn't too much to say about this
one it's the new Forest the area is
known for its maintained gravel paths
making it an excellent choice for a
beginner B packing route the route does
include one bride away that can
sometimes get a bit muddy and overgrown
but it's not too long so it won't slow
your adventure too much the New Forest
is perfect for beginners as it's mostly
flat with just a couple of short climbs
these climbs are quite man manageable
and honestly don't even register as
climbs for the more experienced Riders
however if you are new to cycling you
might find them a little tiring with the
right gearing though you should be just
fine this route found on keepsmiling
adventures.com differs slightly from the
one you'll find on bite packing.com as
it removes the boggy Trail leading out
towards the Roger Penny way which is a
little hard to follow and leads to a bus
Road and thankfully it doesn't cut out
anything worthwhile and it doesn't
shorten the route by much the total
distance is around 60 M making it a
great option for either a single day
ride or a quick overnighter Adventure
what I particularly enjoy about cycling
The New Forest is the opportunity to
soak in the beautiful scenery and
Wildlife get lost in nature of the New
Forest as the New Forest ponies Rope
free whether you're looking for a gentle
introduction to bite back in the
stunning New Forest landscape this route
is a fantastic choice and is no doubt
the easiest most beginner friendly bik
packing route you could take on in the
UK and there you have it five beginner
friendly bike packing routes across the
UK from the beautiful landscapes of the
New Forest to the stunning Coastline of
the gawa each route offers its own
unique charm and challenges where
whether you are tackling the scenic
Trails of the Rebellion way or enjoying
the adventure of the two downs one
Forest if you are looking for a beginner
friendly bike packing route then these
are some of the best routes to start
with in the UK remember the key is to
enjoy the journey so take your time soak
in the views and don't hesitate to stop
and explore bik packing isn't just about
reaching the Finish Line it's about the
experience and memories you create along
the way so keep smiling and enjoy the
adventure it's a beautiful world out
there and just don't pass on the
Dare if you have a will and a moment to
spare it's a beautiful world out there
it's a beautiful world out
there it can be a bit frightening

as you are riding around kent a well
populated area this does make wild
camping a little more harder with remote

so being as stealth as possible is the
best way here the bivvy will give you

hammock camping on this route would not

as possible
plenty of places to start this route

chelsea rai ashford y canterbury
whitstable margate
deal
dover you get the idea this route is

hours
the difficulty of this ride is going to

a very easy

with all of this route as long as you

being such a flat route makes this route

my final rating is going to be a 6 out

personally say this
route is more leaning towards a touring

route being that the majority of this

opposed to off-road
but whatever you want to call it if you
are looking for a nice enjoyable
leisurely trip on your bicycle then this

good spots to have a dip in the sea
the top tip for this route is going to
be to get to whitstable as early as
possible to make a start on the busier
coastal section of this route to really
get to enjoy as the sun rises
so there we have it guys there is my
before you ride the kante way it's a
generally it's a really easy to ride
route there's nothing too technical it's
just like enjoyable lots of like sea
views if you like the sea like i do if
you're drawn to the sea then you'll
definitely just enjoy this as just a
general bike ride it's not overly hard
but it's just it's just nice that is
what i'm saying it's just a nice ride
right guys that is it before you ride if
you enjoyed this video give it a thumbs
up if you are new to the channel
consider subscribing go watch some of
the other bike packing videos and i will

smiling enjoy adventure
peace

videos.title: Ride through Scarborough Whitby and Sandsend
videos.description:
This is a short video showing the beauty of North Yorkshire Coastal fishing towns on a very hot & very busy day in July.
This is Covid post lockdown, a school holiday and fine day - perfect for a day at the beack.
